s.text: In a state lottery, your odds of winning depend only on how many tickets you hold compared with everyone else.
That's a good analogy to an election with many equally plausible candidates whose odds of winning might depend only on how much they spend compared with everyone else.
And if politicians believe that an election is "rigged," in the sense that the favorite will probably win regardless of expenditures, they'll buy fewer campaign commercials.
The second is to reduce the uncertainty about who's going to win.

Likewise, if the presidency is worth $50 million and there are many potential candidates with essentially identical chances of winning, they'll keep entering the race until they've collectively spent at least $50 million.
The first candidate to file would always win by default.
And if politicians believe that an election is "rigged," in the sense that the favorite will probably win regardless of expenditures, they'll buy fewer campaign commercials.
It might even be a reasonably accurate metaphor if we lived in a world where the biggest spender always wins.
So, sooner or later, politicians reach a point where one more commercial just can't justify its cost.
So, sooner or later, politicians reach a point where one more commercial just can't justify its cost.

So, sooner or later, politicians reach a point where one more commercial just can't justify its cost.

Suppose, for example, that Al Gore and George W. Bush are in the middle of a hotly contested race for the presidency when Colin Powell suddenly throws his hat in the ring--and suppose that Powell has a 20 percent chance of winning.
